paragraph.value: Table 3 reports results of the multi-task training procedure described above. We use
language model in our comparisons for each task, i.e.
for image-sentence retrieval and phrase grounding, and the

language model for text-to-clip, image captioning, and VQA. The first lines of Table 3 report the results of the original fixed GrOVLE embedding, which should be considered the baseline. The second line of Table 3 reports performance when the four-task pretrained GrOVLE is fixed when used in the target task, i.e. the task currently being run. The third and fourth line of Table 3 report the results of our embedding when they were trained on all five tasks, and kept fixed or fine-tuned for the target task, respectively.  The results of line three and four demonstrate that our improved embedding tends to transfer better when applied with fine-tuning during the target task. We find similar trends in performance improvements across tasks: larger gains occur for image-sentence retrieval with
mean recall for the Flickr30K dataset and

for MSCOCO. All other tasks have performance improvements under one point, showing that while the vision-language tasks appear to transfer well without harming performance, they are leveraged most in image-sentence retrieval, with an exception of phrase grounding accuracy on ReferIt (
